work.p: This manuscript is similar to a line in a notebook that also contains draft lines of a poem unpublished in Whitman's lifetime, titled "Pictures": "And there, singular, on ocean waves, downward, buoyant, swift, over the waters, an occupied coffin floating." The first several lines of the notebook (not including this line) were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster (1881, p. 310).

titleStmt.title: Downward, buoyant
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

notesStmt.note: This fragmentary manuscript is a version of a line incorporated in the early notebook poem "Pictures." A similar line is also inscribed in the early notebook "I know a rich capitalist," currently housed at the New York Public Library.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: How can there be immortality
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
A series of draft lines written on the back of this manuscript leaf relate to the poem eventually titled "Starting from Paumanok."

body.l:
Downward, buoyant, On turbid waters, wheeling
racing and swift buoyant
swift
coffin floats float
